statement:
We give an example of a subset of the real numbers which is Lebesgue
measurable, but not Borel measurable.

Let $S$ consist of the set of all irrational real numbers with continued
fraction of the form
$$x=a_0+\sfrac{1}{a_1+\sfrac{1}{a_2+\sfrac{1}{\ddots}}}$$ such that
there exists an infinite sequence $0<i_1<i_2<\cdots$ where each
$a_{i_k}$ divides $a_{i_{k+1}}$. It can be shown that this set is
Lebesgue measurable, but not Borel measurable.

In fact, it can be shown that $S$ is an , meaning that it is the image
of a continuous function $f\colon X\rightarrow\mathbb{R}$ for some
Polish space $X$ and, consequently, $S$ is a universally measurable set.

This example is due to Lusin (1927).
names: a Lebesgue measurable but non-Borel set
